name: Red Fort
description: A historic fort and a symbol of India's independence.
history: Built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in 1648, the fort served as the main residence of the Mughal emperors for nearly 200 years.

name: Qutub Minar
description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, the tallest brick minaret in the world.
history: Construction was initiated by Qutb-ud-din Aibak in 1192 and later completed by his successor, Iltutmish.

name: Gateway of India
description: A historic arch-monument built during the 20th century.
history: Constructed in 1924 to commemorate the visit of King George V and Queen Mary to India in 1911.

name: Hawa Mahal
description: A palace known for its unique honeycomb structure with 953 small windows.
history: Built in 1799 by Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh to allow royal women to observe street festivals unseen.

name: Mysore Palace
description: A magnificent palace that serves as the official residence of the Wadiyar dynasty.
history: Rebuilt in 1912 after a fire destroyed the previous structure, it is an architectural marvel blending Hindu, Muslim, Rajput, and Gothic styles.

name: Varanasi Ghats
description: A series of steps leading to the banks of the River Ganges, significant for Hindu rituals.
history: These ghats have been used for religious ceremonies and cremation rituals for over 3,000 years.

name: Ajanta and Ellora Caves
description: Rock-cut caves known for their Buddhist, Hindu, and Jain sculptures and paintings.
history: Ajanta Caves date back to the 2nd century BCE, while the Ellora Caves were built between the 6th and 10th centuries.

name: India Gate
description: A war memorial dedicated to Indian soldiers who died in World War I.
history: Completed in 1931, it commemorates over 70,000 soldiers of the British Indian Army who lost their lives.

name: Ranthambore National Park
description: One of the largest national parks in India, famous for its tiger population.
history: Originally a hunting ground for the Maharajas of Jaipur, it was declared a wildlife sanctuary in 1955 and a national park in 1980.

name: Golden Temple
description: The holiest shrine of Sikhism, covered in gold and known for its spiritual significance.
history: Built in 1581 by Guru Arjan Dev, the temple has been a center of Sikhism for centuries.

name: Charminar
description: A historic monument and mosque known for its four grand minarets.
history: Built in 1591 by Sultan Muhammad Quli Qutb Shah to mark the end of a deadly plague in the city.

name: Sundarbans National Park
description: A UNESCO-listed mangrove forest, home to the Bengal tiger.
history: The Sundarbans forest has been recognized for its ecological significance for centuries and was designated a national park in 1984.

name: Meenakshi Temple
description: A stunning Dravidian-style temple dedicated to Goddess Meenakshi.
history: Believed to have been originally built in the 6th century and later expanded by the Nayak rulers in the 16th century.

name: Konark Sun Temple
description: A 13th-century temple dedicated to the Sun God, known for its intricate carvings.
history: Built in the 13th century by King Narasimhadeva I of the Eastern Ganga dynasty.

name: Kaziranga National Park
description: A UNESCO-listed wildlife sanctuary famous for its one-horned rhinoceroses.
history: Declared a national park in 1974, it has played a crucial role in conserving the Indian rhinoceros.

name: Brihadeeswarar Temple
description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, known for its massive temple tower.
history: Built by the Chola King Rajaraja I in the 11th century.

name: Rishikesh
description: A spiritual town known as the Yoga Capital of the World.
history: Famous for its ancient ashrams and association with Hindu sages for thousands of years.

name: Sanchi Stupa
description: A Buddhist monument built by Emperor Ashoka in the 3rd century BCE.
history: One of the oldest stone structures in India, built to house relics of the Buddha.

name: Taj Mahal
description: An ivory-white marble mausoleum commissioned by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan.
history: Built between 1632 and 1653 in memory of Shah Jahan's wife, Mumtaz Mahal.

name: Varanasi Ghats
description: A series of steps leading to the River Ganges, significant for Hindu rituals.
history: Used for religious ceremonies and cremation rituals for over 3,000 years.

name: Fatehpur Sikri
description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site and former Mughal capital.
history: Built by Emperor Akbar in the 16th century as his capital.

name: Allahabad Triveni Sangam
description: The confluence of the Ganges, Yamuna, and mythical Saraswati rivers.
history: A sacred pilgrimage site for Hindus, especially during the Kumbh Mela.

name: Ayodhya Ram Mandir
description: A major Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Rama.
history: Believed to be the birthplace of Lord Rama, with historical significance dating back thousands of years.

name: Sarnath
description: An important Buddhist site where Lord Buddha delivered his first sermon.
history: Home to the Dhamek Stupa, built by Emperor Ashoka in the 3rd century BCE.

name: Jhansi Fort
description: A 17th-century fort known for its association with Rani Lakshmibai.
history: Played a crucial role in the Revolt of 1857.

name: Dudhwa National Park
description: A national park rich in biodiversity, home to tigers and rhinos.
history: Declared a national park in 1977 to protect endangered species.

name: Mathura Krishna Janmabhoomi
description: A sacred Hindu site believed to be the birthplace of Lord Krishna.
history: An important religious site with temples and historical significance.

name: Kedarnath Temple
description: A sacred Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, part of the Char Dham pilgrimage.
history: Believed to be built by the Pandavas and revived by Adi Shankaracharya in the 8th century.

name: Badrinath Temple
description: A revered Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu, part of the Char Dham yatra.
history: Believed to have been established by Adi Shankaracharya in the 8th century.

name: Har Ki Pauri
description: A famous ghat on the banks of the Ganges River, known for Ganga Aarti.
history: A sacred site believed to be visited by Lord Vishnu and Lord Shiva.

name: Nainital Lake
description: A picturesque natural freshwater lake, a popular tourist attraction.
history: Believed to be one of the 64 Shakti Peethas, where Goddess Sati's eyes fell.

name: Jim Corbett National Park
description: India’s oldest national park, known for its Bengal tiger population.
history: Established in 1936 as Hailey National Park, later renamed after Jim Corbett.

name: Mussoorie
description: A scenic hill station known as the ‘Queen of Hills’.
history: Developed as a hill station by the British in the 19th century.

name: Valley of Flowers National Park
description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, famous for its alpine flowers and biodiversity.
history: Discovered in 1931 by British mountaineer Frank Smythe.

name: Rishikesh
description: A major center for yoga and spirituality, known as the ‘Yoga Capital of the World’.
history: Mentioned in ancient scriptures as a place of meditation and enlightenment.

name: Auli
description: A famous ski resort known for its snow-covered slopes.
history: Developed as a winter sports destination in the late 20th century.

name: Panch Kedar
description: A group of five sacred Shiva temples situated in the Garhwal region.
history: Believed to be established by the Pandavas from the Mahabharata.
